subsection.title: Subspaces: Definition and Examples

statement.p: A subset of \R^n is any collection of points of \R^n.

subsection.p: Above we expressed C in set builder notation: in English, it reads C is the set of all ordered pairs (x,y) in \R^2 such that x^2+y^2=1.

statement.p:
A subspace of \R^n is a subset V of \R^n satisfying:
Non-emptiness: The zero vector is in V.
Closure under addition: If u and v are in V, then u+v is also in V.
Closure under scalar multiplication: If v is in V and c is in \R, then cv is also in V.

subsection.p:
As a consequence of these properties, we see:
If v is a vector in V, then all scalar multiples of v are in V by the third property. In other words the line through any nonzero vector in V is also contained in V.
If u,v are vectors in V and c,d are scalars, then cu,dv are also in V by the third property, so cu+dv is in V by the second property. Therefore, all of \Span\{u,v\} is contained in V
Similarly, if v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n are all in V, then \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_n\} is contained in V. In other words, a subspace contains the span of any vectors in it.
If you choose enough vectors, then eventually their span will fill up V, so we already see that a subspace is a span. See this below for a precise statement.

remark.p: Suppose that V is a non-empty subset of \R^n that satisfies properties 2 and 3. Let v be any vector in V. Then 0v = 0 is in V by the third property, so V automatically satisfies property 1. It follows that the only subset of \R^n that satisfies properties 2 and 3 but not property 1 is the empty subset \{\}. This is why we call the first property non-emptiness.

specialcase.p: The set \R^n is a subspace of itself: indeed, it contains zero, and is closed under addition and scalar multiplication.
The set \{0\} containing only the zero vector is a subspace of \R^n: it contains zero, and if you add zero to itself or multiply it by a scalar, you always get zero.

bluebox.title: Subsets versus Subspaces

subsection.p: In order to verify that a subset of \R^n is in fact a subspace, one has to check the three defining properties. That is, unless the subset has already been verified to be a subspace: see this below.

example.title: Verifying that a subset is a subspace

statement.p: Let V = \left\{ \vec{a b} \text{ in } \R^2 \bigm| 2a = 3b\right\}. Verify that V is a subspace.

solution.p: First we point out that the condition 2a = 3b defines whether or not a vector is in V: that is, to say {a\choose b} is in V means that 2a = 3b. In other words, a vector is in V if twice its first coordinate equals three times its second coordinate. So for instance, {3\choose 2} and {1/2\choose 1/3} are in V, but {2\choose 3} is not because 2\cdot 2\neq 3\cdot 3.
Let us check the first property. The subset V does contain the zero vector {0\choose 0}, because 2\cdot 0 = 3\cdot 0.

Next we check the second property. To show that V is closed under addition, we have to check that for any vectors u = {a\choose b} and v = {c\choose d} in V, the sum u+v is in V. Since we cannot assume anything else about u and v, we must treat them as unknowns.

We have \vec{a b} + \vec{c d} = \vec{a+c b+d}. To say that a+c\choose b+d is contained in V means that 2(a+c) = 3(b+d), or 2a + 2c = 3b + 3d. The one thing we are allowed to assume about u and v is that 2a = 3b and 2c = 3d, so we see that u+v is indeed contained in V.

Next we check the third property. To show that V is closed under scalar multiplication, we have to check that for any vector v = {a\choose b} in V and any scalar c in \R, the product cv is in V. Again, we must treat v and c as unknowns. We have c\vec{a b} = \vec{ca cb}. To say that ca\choose cb is contained in V means that 2(ca) = 3(cb), i.e., that c\cdot 2a = c\cdot 3b. The one thing we are allowed to assume about v is that 2a = 3b, so cv is indeed contained in V.

example.title: Showing that a subset is not a subspace

statement.p: Let V = \left\{ \vec{a b} \text{ in } \R^2\bigm| ab=0 \right\}. Is V a subspace?

solution.p: First we point out that the condition ab=0 defines whether or not a vector is in V: that is, to say {a\choose b} is in V means that ab=0. In other words, a vector is in V if the product of its coordinates is zero, i.e., if one (or both) of its coordinates are zero. So for instance, {1\choose 0} and {0\choose 2} are in V, but {1\choose 1} is not because 1\cdot 1\neq 0.
Let us check the first property. The subset V does contain the zero vector {0\choose 0}, because 0\cdot 0=0.

Next we check the third property. To show that V is closed under scalar multiplication, we have to check that for any vector v = {a\choose b} in V and any scalar c in \R, the product cv is in V. Since we cannot assume anything else about v and c, we must treat them as unknowns.

We have c\vec{a b} = \vec{ca cb}. To say that ca\choose cb is contained in V means that (ca)(cb)=0. Rewriting, this means c^2(ab)=0. The one thing we are allowed to assume about v is that ab=0, so we see that cv is indeed contained in V.

subsection.title: Common Types of Subspaces

theorem.title: Spans are Subspaces and Subspaces are Spans

statement.p: If v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p are any vectors in \R^n, then \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p\} is a subspace of \R^n. Moreover, any subspace of \R^n can be written as a span of a set of p linearly independent vectors in \R^n for p\leq n.

proof.p:
To show that \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p\} is a subspace, we have to verify the three defining properties.
The zero vector 0 = 0v_1 + 0v_2 + \cdots + 0v_p is in the span.
If u = a_1v_1 + a_2v_2 + \cdots + a_pv_p and v = b_1v_1 + b_2v_2 + \cdots + b_pv_p are in \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p\}, then u + v = (a_1+b_1)v_1 + (a_2+b_2)v_2 + \cdots + (a_p+b_p)v_p is also in \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p\}.
If v = a_1v_1 + a_2v_2 + \cdots + a_pv_p is in \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p\} and c is a scalar, then cv = ca_1v_1 + ca_2v_2 + \cdots + ca_pv_p is also in \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p\}.
Since \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p\} satisfies the three defining properties of a subspace, it is a subspace.

Now let V be a subspace of \R^n. If V is the zero subspace, then it is the span of the empty set, so we may assume V is nonzero. Choose a nonzero vector v_1 in V. If V = \Span\{v_1\}, then we are done. Otherwise, there exists a vector v_2 that is in V but not in \Span\{v_1\}. Then \Span\{v_1,v_2\} is contained in V, and by the increasing span criterion, the set \{v_1,v_2\} is linearly independent. If V = \Span\{v_1,v_2\} then we are done. Otherwise, we continue in this fashion until we have written V = \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p\} for some linearly independent set \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p\}. This process terminates after at most n steps by this .

subsection.p: If V = \Span\{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p\}, we say that V is the subspace spanned by or generated by the vectors v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p. We call \{v_1,v_2,\ldots,v_p\} a spanning set for V.
Any matrix naturally gives rise to two subspaces.

statement.p:
Let A be an m\times n matrix.
The column space of A is the subspace of \R^m spanned by the columns of A. It is written \Col(A).
The null space of A is the subspace of \R^n consisting of all solutions of the homogeneous equation Ax=0: \Nul(A) = \bigl\{ x \text{ in } \R^n\bigm| Ax=0 \bigr\}.

subsection.p: Column spaceis a subspace The column space is defined to be a span, so it is a subspace by the above . We need to verify that the null space is really a subspace. In we already saw that the set of solutions of Ax=0 is always a span, so the fact that the null spaces is a subspace should not come as a surprise.

proof.p:
We have to verify the three defining properties. To say that a vector v is in \Nul(A) means that Av = 0.
The zero vector is in \Nul(A) because A0=0.
Suppose that u,v are in \Nul(A). This means that Au=0 and Av=0. Hence A(u+v) = Au + Av = 0 + 0 = 0 by the linearity of the matrix-vector product. Therefore, u+v is in \Nul(A).
Suppose that v is in \Nul(A) and c is a scalar. Then A(cv) = cAv = c\cdot 0 = 0 by the linearity of the matrix-vector product, so cv is also in \Nul(A).
Since \Nul(A) satisfies the three defining properties of a subspace, it is a subspace.

statement.p: Describe the column space and the null space ofA = \mat{1 1; 1 1; 1 1}.

solution.p: Notice that the column space is a subspace of \R^3, whereas the null space is a subspace of \R^2. This is because A has three rows and two columns.

subsection.p: The column space and the null space of a matrix are both subspaces, so they are both spans. The column space of a matrix A is defined to be the span of the columns of A. The null space is defined to be the solution set of Ax=0, so this is a good example of a kind of subspace that we can define without any spanning set in mind. In other words, it is easier to show that the null space is a subspace than to show it is a spansee the proof above. In order to do computations, however, it is usually necessary to find a spanning set.

specialcase.title: Null Spaces are Solution Sets

subsection.p: To find a spanning set for the null space, one has to solve a system of homogeneous equations.

bluebox.title: Recipe: Compute a spanning set for a null space
bluebox.p: To find a spanning set for \Nul(A), compute the parametric vector form of the solutions to the homogeneous equation Ax=0. The vectors attached to the free variables form a spanning set for \Nul(A).

statement.p: Find a spanning set for the null space of the matrix A = \mat{2 3 -8 -5; -1 2 -3 -8}.

solution.p:
We compute the parametric vector form of the solutions of Ax=0. The reduced row echelon form of A is \mat{1 0 -1 2; 0 1 -2 -3}. The free variables are x_3 and x_4; the parametric form of the solution set is
\syseq{x_1 = x_3 - 2x_4; x_2 = 2x_3 + 3x_4; x_3 = x_3; x_4 = \. \+ x_4} \quad\xrightarrow[\text{vector form}]{\text{parametric}}\quad \vec{x_1 x_2 x_3 x_4} = x_3\vec{1 2 1 0} + x_4\vec{-2 3 0 1}.
Therefore, \Nul(A) = \Span\left\{\vec{1 2 1 0},\;\vec{-2 3 0 1}\right\}.

statement.p: Find a spanning set for the null space of the matrix A = \mat{1 3; 2 4}.

solution.p: We compute the parametric vector form of the solutions of Ax=0. The reduced row echelon form of A is \mat{1 0; 0 1}. There are no free variables; hence the only solution of Ax=0 is the trivial solution. In other words, \Nul(A) = \{0\} = \Span\{0\}. It is natural to define \Span\{\} = \{0\}, so that we can take our spanning set to be empty. This is consistent with the definition of dimension.

paragraphs.title: Writing a subspace as a column space or a null space

idx.h: writing as column or null space

paragraphs.p: A subspace can be given to you in many different forms. In practice, computations involving subspaces are much easier if your subspace is the column space or null space of a matrix. The simplest example of such a computation is finding a spanning set: a column space is by definition the span of the columns of a matrix, and we showed above how to compute a spanning set for a null space using parametric vector form. For this reason, it is useful to rewrite a subspace as a column space or a null space before trying to answer questions about it.

bluebox.p: When asking questions about a subspace, it is usually best to rewrite the subspace as a column space or a null space.

paragraphs.p: This also applies to the question is my subset a subspace? If your subset is a column space or null space of a matrix, then the answer is yes.

specialcase.p: Let V = \left\{ \vec{a b} \text{ in } \R^2 \bigm| 2a = 3b\right\} be the subset of a previous . The subset V is exactly the solution set of the homogeneous equation 2x - 3y = 0. Therefore, V = \Nul\mat{2 -3}. In particular, it is a subspace. The reduced row echelon form of \mat{2 -3} is \mat{1 -3/2}, so the parametric form of V is x = 3/2y, so the parametric vector form is {x\choose y} = y{3/2\choose 1}, and hence \bigl\{{3/2\choose 1}\bigr\} spans V.

statement.p:
Let V be the plane in \R^3 defined by
V = \left\{\vec{2x+y x-y 3x-2y}\bigm| x,y \text{ are in } \R \right\}.
Write V as the column space of a matrix.

solution.p: Since \vec{2x+y x-y 3x-2y} = x\vec{2 1 3} + y\vec{1 -1 -2}, we notice that V is exactly the span of the vectors \vec{2 1 3} \sptxt{and} \vec{1 -1 -2}. Hence V = \Col\mat{2 1; 1 -1; 3 -2}.
